description.narrative:
South Africa is one of the most unequal countries in the world. The country has a history of labour exploitation stemming from colonialism, slavery and apartheid – which were all systems that ensured that farms especially and other industries used black people ascheap labour with little to no rights or recourse. Trade Unions traditionally used to fight for workers’ rights but with the decrease in permanent employees they are also struggling as they rely on the payment of monthly fees by employed peopleto survive. An increasingly casualised workforce has meant that the trade union space has shrunk considerably as casual workers often don’t join unions. The South Africa Department of Labour is also often understaffed and so even when they are called outby workers, observe and fine companies for failing to uphold labour rights, the department often does not have the capacity to do the kind of regular progress updates and checking on employers that is needed for consistent adherence to labour regulations. Along with the monopoly that is growing in the food retail sector in South Africa with the five biggest supermarkets taking over from smaller community markets, the power dynamics between workers and companies in the food retail sector in the country can only be described as extremely unequal. This campaign aims to address this inequality. As planned, in April 2022 the Behind the Barcode/Price (BtBP) campaign will enjoy a significant shift in strategy, The next phase of the campaign is all about “walkingthe talk”. Whilst we have seen substantive new commitments from retailers, we now need to see these translated into practical policies which are then implemented across their vast and complex supply chains. Moving forward we will focus on how differentretailers, and their suppliers, are ensuring a better deal for frontline communities. We have planned a strong Public Communications Moment through which to amplify our demands for accountability. Ongoing advocacy work will engage relevant public and private stakeholders to address inequality in food value chains internationally, including national campaigning in South Africa. In April 2022, a digital package will be released to support campaigners, including social media tools and a digital platform. Ongoing monitoring of private sector implementation of BtBP campaign commitments will take place including use of Oxfam's Human Rights Impact Assessment (HRIA) framework that will be published this year.
In South Africa,relevant private sector partners will be convened through stakeholder roundtables around South African Women’s Day, to launch a report on women casual workers and labour rights. Also, Oxfam in South Africa will provide 2 online digital campaign design workshops for local workers, women, and/or public supporters.

participating-org.narrative: Oxfam South Africa is an independent Oxfam affiliate who manages and implements the programme of Oxfam in South Africa. Its programme prioritises vulnerable communities and creating lasting change in, and for all the people in South Africa. Oxfam South Africa works in partnership with organisations who seek to create meaningful and sustainable change that benefits vulnerable groups in South Africa through the attainment, protection and preservation of human rights and social justice. The country program will continue to focus its work through ‘active citizenship and accountability’ and ‘gender justice’ lenses.
